user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemDelete_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemDelete_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                              status;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    status = pthread_mutex_destroy(&(impl->id)); /* 0 = success */

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemDelete_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t OS_impl_mutex_table[OS_MAX_MUTEXES]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t id;
} OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch(OS_ObjectMatchFunc_t MatchFunc, void *arg, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32               return_code;
    uint32              obj_count;
    OS_common_record_t *base;
    OS_common_record_t *record;

    return_code   = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    base          = &OS_common_table[OS_GetBaseForObjectType(token->obj_type)];
    obj_count     = OS_GetMaxForObjectType(token->obj_type);
    token->obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    while (true)
    {
        ++token->obj_idx;

        if (token->obj_idx >= obj_count)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(base, *token);

        if (OS_ObjectIdDefined(record->active_id) && MatchFunc(arg, token, record))
        {
            return_code   = OS_SUCCESS;
            token->obj_id = record->active_id;
            break;
        }
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
bool OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext(OS_object_iter_t *iter)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    bool                got_next;

    got_next           = false;
    iter->token.obj_id = OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED;

    do
    {
        ++iter->token.obj_idx;
        if (iter->token.obj_idx >= iter->limit)
        {
            break;
        }

        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(iter->base, iter->token);
        if (iter->match == NULL || iter->match(iter->arg, &iter->token, record))
        {
            iter->token.obj_id = record->active_id;
            got_next           = true;
        }
    } while (!got_next);

    return got_next;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No direct use of memcmp or any string.h functions is present in the provided code fragments. The OS_MutSemDelete_Impl function only calls pthread_mutex_destroy on a pthread_mutex_t member and returns status codes — there are no string comparisons there. The OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET macro and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken operate on integer indices and tokens (obj_idx), not strings. The loops in OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch and OS_ObjectIdIteratorGetNext advance indices and inspect record->active_id (an identifier), not character buffers. The only places that could plausibly perform string comparisons (and thus potentially use memcmp on null-terminated strings) are the callback invocations MatchFunc(...) and iter->match(...); their implementations are not included here and therefore are flagged for investigation. All other shown code does not involve string operations and therefore does not need to be investigated for MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
